subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS POLL RESPONSES
msgSnippet: David: Thanks for the clarification of your responses to the poll.  I m glad we were able to flush you of the bushes, which, apparently, are full of lurkers.
messageBody:
David:
 
Thanks for the clarification of your responses to the poll.  I'm glad we were able to flush you of the bushes, which, apparently, are full of lurkers.  My experience is that it takes steady use to become fluent in QS.  Since most of us use QS for personal notes, as opposed to writing to others, it is not easy to get sufficient reading and writing practice.  To become fluent in QS takes dedication and persistence in its use.  I would encourage you to begin the effort.  When you consider how surrounded we are by TO, and how much time the average person has spent reading TO since childhood, it is not surprising that QS fluency cannot be achieved with minimal effort.
 
As a humorous aside, when I was in law school, a fellow student asked me if she could borrow my notes from a class she had been unable to attend.  Without thinking about the fact that roughly 1/3 of my notes were in QS, I loaned them to her.  The following day she returned and thanked me but said my notes hadn't been all that helpful, and, by the way, "what is this", she asked, pointing to the numerous spots where the professor had been speaking quickly enough that I had shifted into QS.
 
You can start out small and take portions of your graduate school notes in QS.  I used to mix TO and QS together in the same sentence, which made it easier for me to increase my fluency as the portions in TO made it easier to anticipate what the portions in QS were about.  Just as TO readers don't sound most words out, but recognize word shapes, QS readers have to build up a sufficient base word recognition to develop any reading speed in QS. 
 
Good luck.
 
Paige
----- Original Message -----
From: David Dailey
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, March 24, 2005 1:23 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS POLL RESPONSES


Thanks, Paige, for all your work on this group.  I've been reading
the
group for a couple of years now but this is my first post.  I've just
responded to the poll and wanted to comment on my responses.  Maybe
these notes can serve as inspiration to other infrequent posters go
fill out the polls and give you a better idea of how this community
uses Quikscript.

I answered that I don't use Quikscript, because since I first ran
across it a couple of years ago I haven't had (or made) the time to
work with it regularly enough to be comfortable.  And I haven't made
it part of my regular routine at this point.  Maybe when I'm done
with
graduate school...

In spite of not using it, I answered "1-2 years" on the second
question-- because that reflects when I started exploring it.

--David

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@a...>
wrote:
>
> We have 247 members today.  Just wanted to remind everyone that I
set
> up a brief poll some weeks back in an attempt to gauge how members
are
> using quicksript and how long they have used it.  I have 14 answers
on
> question 1 and 11 on question 2.  If you have not answered the
> question, please take a minute to answer them. 
>
> Thanks
